147348317.review:
This is such a delightful video game that has become an instant favorite in our family!

What I really liked about it are characters that are very charming and cute and graphics are very different in terms of how colorful and vibrant they are. Very different and refreshing from all the other standard modern games. The attention to detail is very good.

The gameplay is easy to grasp, making it accessible for younger players while still offering a challenge for the more experienced gamers. It's the perfect balance of fun and a little bit of strategy as you progress further in the game. 

One of the standout features of the game is that's very family-friendly oriented. It's refreshing these days to find a game that doesn't rely on violence or inappropriate themes. It's just very simple, you log in and get straight into the fun shamelessly eating everything that's on your way + bonus points when you can play with your friends or kids where you need to work together. It's really fantastic to see my family members shouting: ''Nooo, help me the dog is chasing me'' or ''Throw the bomb, throw the bomb!!!''. Very joyful and funny with lots of laughs. 

I got to say music is veeeery catchy and sound effects of animals and all other aspects are adorable which brings overall charm of the game. 

I don't leave reviews very often but for this I gladly took my time to write one. It's a wholesome, family-oriented experience that promotes bonding and laughter. It's a game that grandparents can enjoy with their grandkids, siblings can play together, and parents can have a blast with their children. As said, it's a rare gem that brings everyone closer in a world filled with violent and complex video games and this is a shining example of entertainment that we need to see more. 

It will leave smile on your face and a craving for pizza in your heart and belly. So, gather your family, order some pizza, and dive into the delightful world of Pizza Possum. You definitely won't be disappointed!

147343286.review: It's so fun! The chaos and the thrill of getting chased is exciting, especially with coop. Playing solo is fun too, I had tons of fun and I invited my bf to play he loved it too. The graphics, mechanics and gameplay is short and simple but it doesn't get too repetitive. The regions were well designed and the items, were given much attention,providing interesting tools to help you sneak away and are all unique on their own. Great job devs!

147342515.review: Played w friend. Laugh a lot. hihi. A good fun short game.AnywAY, need more levels. Please have dlcs or expansion.

147334345.review:
A fast paced and simple game that anyone can reasonably play. As reductive as it can be to just compare games to other games its often an easy baseline to set expectations. This game spiritually shares a lot of its DNA with Pac-Man and Untitled Goose Game. You are a mischevious little gremlin of an opossum who will eat any and every food in its sight. You scamper about in what at times feels like a stealth game but always maintains a pace where you never feel like you're bogged down in some nasty stealth section. With clever play you can run around and evade captors just as easily as you can sneak past them. 

This is the perfect sort of game to play on a Steam Deck with simple controls and a quick yet engaging gameplay loop. It's not the most world shattering game ever made but it doesn't have to be, especially not for a price this low. It's an arcade-y title through and through, fast and frantic with enough there that it'll be fun to pickup in bursts here and there for a while. If you've got a few bucks burning in your pocket and want something that'll put a smile on your face and keep you engaged for a while, this is a perfectly fine pickup.

147312759.review:
I just finished the game so I'll be as critical and detailed as possible.

General Overview
---------------------------------
You're a possum, a pizza-loving possum at that, for some reason the entire town already hates you because of your predisposition to eat everyone's food. The king, King Doggy Boy if you will, is whipping up a mighty fine and big pizza; this, be as it may, is the very thing you want in life, King Doggy Boy's pizza.

You get a couple of power ups and try to sneakily (or very blatantly, whichever is your style) go around the town eating the peoples food to obtain keys, which unlock the doors to higher elevations on Mt. Doggy; in which, at the very top, is the pizza of your dreams.

Once you completely obliterate King Doggy Boy's pizza, you get the Kings crown and need to do that 2 more times back-to-back without getting caught to complete the main game.

Therefore: its a solid 9.5/10 an amazing little game that doesn't overdue its stay, a masterpiece of the small-time games. I love it

THE ONLY CONS THAT I HAVE:
1.) I wish it was longer and had a variety of pizza-related things
2.) That instead of losing all the crowns when getting caught, make it so that you only lose one. (so if you have 2 crowns, you get caught, and restart at 1 crown)

besides that, awesome game !

147308914.review:
[h2]*Screams* Aaaaah![/h2]
Pizza Possum is a simple and enjoyable Co-Op or single player experience in which you play as a Possum who desperately wants to eat, more especially to prove to that arrogant queen that you're good enough to eat their pizza locked high in the castle! 

Frantically run around like the crazy little *OMNOMWF* marsupial as you try to eat as much as you can without getting caught by the Queens henchmen. Can you escape capture and eat all the things (3) times in a row!? 

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
It's humorous, tough, and hectic all at the same time. I really like what's here and wish I could play it with someone, but I don't know many people who would want to play a game like this Co-op. I'm sure it would make the game ten times more enjoyable. Not to say it isn't delightful on its own; it certainly is. It's not trying hard to be anything but pure fun!

147239753.review:
I was eying this game since I first played the demo. I grabbed it as soon as it was released, and I must say I haven't had so much fun playing a game for quite some time. One of the best, enjoyable games I played.


Pros:
+ great music track, it is well balanced, does not get annoying
+ love the art style
+ super fast pace, that comes natural (I'm not a fan of fast pace qte games but in this one I enjoyed the fast speed)
+ you don't feel bad when you loose the game
+ love the different unlockables
+ coop
+ although repetitive you want to play it again and again. 
+ easy enough so my kids can enjoy it

Cons:
- low replay ability value (I still want to play it, but I wonder how much time will pass before it starts to get boring)
- to short (at least single run is to short)
- only 2 player coop, if the game had 4 player coop, it would make it my top 1 party game :)
- to easy (? I haven't had time to replay the game enough times, so I don't know if the difficulty changes, I did not notice it), perhaps some iron man mode would be nice?

CONSUME PIZZA

147225174.review:
Every once in a while it's nice to get out of your comfort zone, explore different genres than you're used to, and give a chance to games or mechanics that didn't seem appealing at first. Thanks to Pizza Possum, I had the chance to experience this, and I'm glad I did. The game is presented to us in an arcade style and puts us in the role of a sneaky possum with a very clear purpose: to fill its belly. Between hiding and running away from the guards, colorful and cartoon-ish visuals, and simple controls that offer excellent accessibility, this is a game that aims for the most basic and essential aspect of a game: fun; and in my opinion, it works well.

Pizza Possum leaves aside complexity and complicated settings and focuses on getting us right into the action with only a brief introduction to the game. Basically, we’ll be a sneaky and extremely hungry possum, who seeks to satisfy its stomach no matter what, and what better target than a freshly baked pizza? I feel identified. Even so, she will leave no plate or basket untouched on her way.

To reach our goal, we’ll have to eat what we find around us while exploring enclosed areas. As we eat we generate points for our high-score, filling a bar that once complete will grant us a key to continue advancing; sometimes you can choose between different paths, but they are very specific rooms. By the way, I should add that you have to be careful with eating too much and too fast, because it can cause our character to get fat and lose speed... almost like in real life, huh?

But if that were all, the game would be a bit simple and not so interesting, so the game also has other obstacles that will stand in our way, in the form of guard dogs. These guards will be on the lookout, patrolling or guarding specific points in the areas, and will chase us as soon as we catch their attention. There are several types of watchdogs, some with their own abilities such as calling for reinforcements, and if they manage to capture us they will send us back to the start or to a checkpoint, if we have passed through one.

There are several ways in which we can avoid being captured, being the first and easiest: dodging. The controls are extremely simple, we move with the directional pad and we have an interaction button, so with a little skill we can evade our pursuers; although perhaps it is easier said than done, so if we find ourselves in a somewhat more problematic situation we can hide in the bushes and wait for the danger to pass, as long as we don’t hide right in front of them!

Sometimes it can be very difficult to just run and hide, but for moments like this we'll also have objects that are unlocked as our score increases, and will be of great help to avoid being caught. These items are obtained progressively, and we'll have energy drinks to run faster, traffic fences that the guards can not cross (they are very honest and polite), or even a canine guardian disguise to eat around them without being noticed.

These objects are found in special boxes, and while there are various types, we are allowed to carry only one at a time, except for passive bonuses such as a mask that make us more difficult to discern. Fortunately, when we replace one of these bonuses the other remains on the floor and can be picked up at any time. One thing I did a lot was to take the energy drink, drink it, and replace it with something else, thus having the speed boost and another item to use at any time. Big brain time!

The only thing I didn't like as much was that when you get the score needed for an upgrade, the score resets; in that case, accumulating a lot of points plays against us in that aspect, because the leftover ones are wasted, and there is no way (or I didn't find it) to know if we have enough score for an upgrade or not without having to get caught. On top of that, sometimes invisible guards would appear, which you can imagine creates very uncomfortable situations! (This is clearly a bug, though).

As we progress, the security grows more active and the areas get more difficult, and it becomes quite challenging as we get closer to the goal. Once we deal with the security and are able to scarf down the freshly baked pizza, we'll acquire a crown and a new mission: to be crowned three times. Here, in my opinion, the difficulty increases significantly, not only because of the number of tenacious guards that appear on the map, but because getting caught means losing the crowns we carry with us. I must say that this was especially challenging for me.

Among all that, I had moments that were very frantic and hilarious, like being chased by half a pack of guard dogs while the character was trying its best to escape with a chubby body. These types of situations were what entertained me the most in the game, making me say phrases like "Run, little one, run!" in the excitement of the moment. And it becomes even more fun in multiplayer, which is one of the other main features of the game, and which I was able to try out a little by taking my nephew hostage. It's worth noting that it's local multiplayer, for the time being.

The biggest difference with multiplayer is that when one of the two players is caught, the other player can approach to help them (without having to press anything, just get close enough to the captor), and that the screen splits in two when we are separated from our partner. I must say that we tried to stay as close as possible, because the split camera adds another layer of extra difficulty, for the simple reason that it reduces our range of vision and many times the guards will see you before they even come on screen. A bit complex, but it is what it is, and probably can be mitigated on higher resolutions.

I've come to the conclusion that Pizza Possum is a game that puts gameplay and fun front and center, in pursuit of making our experience as players enjoyable and entertaining. It has cute and cartoonish visuals, and a soundtrack that combines well with the theme, and both sections make a ribbon that finishes wrapping up the game. Some details that I found cute were for example a sound that indicates when an object is cooling down, or the funny little voices of the characters when they patrol, chase us and so on.

As I mentioned before, it's a title I might have passed on another time, but I'm glad I tried it. It's perfect for a fun time, it lends itself to replayability for those who like to improve and beat their high-scores, and I think it's also ideal for those looking to have a few laughs in multiplayer.
